Project Outcomes Report: Beijing Water Ecosystem Services

NSF EAPSI 2010- Beijing, China

Christina Wong

Contact's NSF ID: 000553165

 

            The NSF EAPSI 2010 China program introduced me to a unique case study for my dissertation research in Beijing, China. I am examining the use of ecological engineering in cities to promote sustainable development. Designed ecosystems or ecological restoration can come in the form of parks, green spaces, lakes, wetlands, etc. They can be important recreational and community spaces for urban residents and can provide valuable cooling and stormwater benefits.  For my dissertation I am evaluating the potential tradeoffs of the Yongding Green Ecological Corridor, an ecological engineering project, in Beijing China.  The main objectives of my research are to increase our understanding of ecological engineering in cities, the connection between ecosystem services and human welfare, and environmental management in China.

            The NSF EAPSI 2010 program afforded me the opportunity to work with Professor Ouyang Zhiyun at the Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS) State Key Laboratory of Urban & Regional Ecology, Research Center of Eco-Environmental Sciences (RCEES). I chose to work with Professor Ouyang since he is a leading authority in China on urban ecology and urban ecosystem services, which are my research areas of interest. Professor Ouyang is the director of the State Key Laboratory of Urban & Regional Ecology and the co-director of the RCEES. In 2005, Arizona State University, my home institution, formed a Joint Center on Urban Sustainability with CAS.  Professor Ouyang is a member of the collaborative since he manages the Beijing urban ecology station, which is equivalent to the NSF urban long-term ecological research sites in Phoenix and Baltimore.  In 2009, Professor Ouyang with several other experts helped lead the first comprehensive assessment on Beijing’s water ecosystem services, which was authorized by the Beijing Water Authority. Ecosystem services are the benefits people obtain from ecosystems, such as water purification, aesthetic landscapes, and climate change mitigation. For my dissertation I wanted to work on urban water ecosystem services in China, hence Professor Ouyang and the State Key Laboratory of Urban & Regional Ecology were a perfect match.  Based on my research interests Professor Ouyang suggested I examine the potential ecosystem services from the Yongding Green Ecological Corridor.

Worldwide experts deem water the most limiting factor for Beijing to meet its current and projected growth (UNEP, 2009). Water scarcity however is only one of several sustainability dilemmas facing Beijing since it also aims to resolve air pollution from dust storms, heat waves exacerbated by the urban heat island effect, carbon-dioxide emissions from automobiles, citizen demands for environmental and cultural amenities, and equitable economic development (Zhou et al. 2006). The need for multi-faceted solutions led Beijing to consider incorporating ecological engineering into urban design. In 2010 the Beijing Municipal Government authorized the construction of the Green Yongding Ecological Corridor. The Yongding River is the largest river in Beijing, yet damming, increased upstream use, and urbanization led to its eventual dewatering.
